At that time, the World-Honored One, having begged for alms in the great city of Shravasti, reached a certain empty place on the way. There was an abandoned infant, with a dignified appearance, extremely fair and bright, sucking on his right thumb. In that empty place, there were many foxes, wolves, and dogs, but they saw the infant and licked him, then left without being able to harm him.
This infant was a person with merit and virtue, who had long planted good roots.
Many people stayed to watch, giving rise to a rare state of mind. They went to watch the abandoned child in the empty place, dignified and lovable, joyful and happy to see the infant.
At that time, the World-Honored One saw many people coming and going in the empty place. Knowing deliberately, he said to Ananda:

At that time, the World-Honored One, out of compassion for the infant, contemplated his past wholesome roots and knew they were already mature, that he would be able to understand the Dharma and meaning I speak of, and also knew that the wholesome roots of sentient beings were mature. He then went to where the infant was.
Having arrived, he stood to one side and spoke a verse to the infant, saying:
The evil karma created in the past is now manifesting its retribution;
abandoned in this empty place, the infant's suffering is like this.
At that time, the infant, empowered by the Buddha's spiritual power and his own wholesome power, replied to the Buddha in verse:
Gautama, you still have views, abandoning the thought of emptiness,
When the Honored One was in the place of practice, did you not know this was a thought?
At that time, the World-Honored One again replied in verse:
I have already known the thought, but I am forever without thought;
Out of compassion for you, I have come to this empty place.
At that time, the infant again spoke in verse:
If sentient beings are not obtained, they are ultimately unobtainable;
Whom does the Honored One have compassion for?
Whose mind of compassion is turned?
At that time, the World-Honored One again spoke in verse:
Sentient beings do not know this, the emptiness and quiescent extinction of no-self;
In order to awaken them, I go to villages and cities.
At that time, the infant again spoke in verse:
Understanding emptiness and quiescence, awakening to emptiness and quiescence;

At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse in reply:

In order to teach and transform sentient beings, the Guide expounds the Dharma.
At that time the infant spoke a verse again:
Still there are inversions. Has the TathÄgata not eliminated them?
Without the notion of sentient beings arising, does compassion arise in this way?
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse in reply:
The Buddha's protection and upholding, bodhisattvas give rise to diligence,
For the sake of sentient beings who do not understand, the Honored One among humans gives rise to adornment.
At that time the infant spoke a verse again:
This is the adornment of delusion;
If one does not obtain things, if dharmas are not things, how can adornment arise?
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
This great compassionate spiritual power, the Tamer of the World is like this,
Still not attached to things, he expounds the Dharma for sentient beings.
At that time the infant spoke a verse again, saying:
The Dharma has no written characters, how can it be expounded?
The great loss in the world is expounding the Dharma as non-Dharma.
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse again, saying:
I do not destroy the world, I do not expound the Dharma as non-Dharma,
Sentient beings themselves are confused and deluded, I liberate them from those bonds.
At that time the infant spoke a verse again, saying:
The afflictions have no root, nor do they have a location,
And they are neither inside nor outside, from what do you liberate those bonds?
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse again, saying:
Arising from false imagination, together with inversion,
In order to sever their false thoughts, O infant!ğŸ”½
In order to sever their false thoughts, I speak the Dharma for them, O infant!
At that time the infant spoke a verse again, saying:
The nature of the mind is originally pure, there are no knots of defilements within it;
Even if there are many false thoughts, the pure nature does not give rise to defilements.
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse again, saying:
It is just as you have said, the nature of the mind is originally pure;
The defilements of guest afflictions, the ignorant give rise to defilements.
At that time the infant spoke a verse again, saying:
The knots have no fixed location, nor can they be obtained from a location;
How is it called arising?
Please explain it for me.
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse again, saying:
Just like clouds in the sky, they can be seen but are not real;
The arising of afflictions is like this, although seen they are not real.
At that time the infant spoke a verse again, saying:
The same as the true nature of dharmas, its arising nature is also thus;
If dharmas are real, not thusness cannot be attained.

All non-thusness dharmas equally abide within thusness;
Having realized this thusness, there are no faults and no merits.
At that time the infant spoke a verse, saying:

Who is the one who is combined?
First observe the basis of dharmas, from whom do afflictions arise?
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
The past, future, and present worlds,
The Buddha knows and realizes, and expounds the Dharma for sentient beings.

KauÅ›ika!
The bodhisattva's mind of enlightenment is the bodhisattva's clothing, until the bodhi seat is fully accomplished and all the Buddha's teachings are perfected.
Having a sense of shame and conscience is the bodhisattva's clothing, for taming and accomplishing all sentient beings and placing them in a state beyond faults.
Firmly adorned vows are the bodhisattva's clothing, for accomplishing all matters.

At that time, King Prasenajit said to the World-Honored One:
This inconceivable light Bodhisattva child has accomplished such supreme and wondrous great Dharma;
What karmic hindrances did he have that he was born in the womb of that prostitute and abandoned in an empty place?
The Buddha told the great king:

In the past, ninety-one kalpas ago, there was a Buddha named VipaÅ›yin who appeared in the world - a TathÄgata, an Arhat, a Perfectly Enlightened One, Perfect in Knowledge and Conduct, a Sugata, an Understander of the World, an Unsurpassed One, a Tamer of Men, a Teacher of Gods and Men, a Buddha, a World-Honored One - Great King, you should know that at that time in the Dharma of VipaÅ›yin TathÄgata there were two bodhisattvas:

He repeatedly reprimanded and taught him, and he became angry and displeased.

At that time, the bodhisattva Xiantian immediately abandoned him.

Having abandoned him, he became even more angry, scolded and slandered him. Due to the causes and conditions of this unwholesome karmic action, when his body perished and his life ended, he was reborn in the womb of a prostitute - protected by the bodhisattva Xiantian, he was not reborn in hell - but the prostitute always abandoned him, to be eaten by foxes, wolves, and dogs.
Great King!
For this reason, for ninety-one kalpas he always died like this, being abandoned in every life, and was scolded by many people, saying:
'You are a prostitute.'
Being abandoned in an empty place, he was eaten by foxes, wolves, and dogs.
Great King, do not doubt.
Why is it so?
The one who was Jijian at that time, who scolded the bodhisattva in anger, is none other than the present bodhisattva Bujingguang.
When evil karma is exhausted, by the power of good karma, purifying the mind of afflictions and delighting the Buddha's intention, this person's evil paths will all be completely extinguished.
Great King!

This inconceivable light Bodhisattva has already encountered 6.4 billion Buddhas, respectfully made offerings and praised them, and under these Buddhas always cultivated pure conduct and diligently sought the Dharma.
By the power of this original goodness, he has attained such matters and the power of spiritual penetrations.

Such black and white karma will never be lost. Therefore, the wise protect their bodily, verbal, and mental actions well. They would rather give up their lives than create evil karma.
At that time, King Prasenajit said:
World-Honored One!
Has that Virtuous Heavenly Bodhisattva already attained omniscience?
Or is he still cultivating bodhisattva practices?
The Buddha said:
Great King!
That Worthy Heaven Bodhisattva is now practicing bodhisattva conduct in that Aká¹£obhya Buddha Land, named 'Merit Treasury.'
At that time, King Prasenajit said:
World-Honored One!
If good men and good women should always be close to good and virtuous friends, and associate with good and virtuous friends.
Why is it so?
World-Honored One!

Associating with good and virtuous friends, respectfully surrounding them and listening to the good Dharma, having heard the good Dharma, one attains a good mind. Having a good mind, one cultivates good conduct, creates good karma, and heads towards good places. One attains good and virtuous friends;
Because of attaining good friends, one does not create any evil, but cultivates all that is good;
Having cultivated all that is good, one is not troubled oneself and does not trouble others.
If a bodhisattva protects oneself and protects others, one can attain enlightenment;
If one has already abided in the path, with great power, one can benefit others.
The Buddha said:
Excellent, Great King!
It is excellent to speak these words.
Great King!
Bodhisattvas, in close proximity to the good and virtuous friends, are fully endowed with all meritorious good dharmas.
At that time, the Bodhisattva Inconceivable Light said:
World-Honored One!
How many dharmas does a bodhisattva accomplish in order to quickly attain supreme, perfect enlightenment and attain the pure acceptance of the Dharma?
The Buddha said:
Child!
A bodhisattva who accomplishes four dharmas will quickly attain the unsurpassed true path and the pure acceptance of the Dharma.
What are the four?

Accepting dependent origination, being free from annihilationism and eternalism, understanding the absence of self, person, sentient being, and life, and understanding emptiness and practicing emptiness.
These are the four.
There are also four dharmas.
What are the four?
The past is quiescent, the future is known to be without coming, the present is not abiding, and the three times are equal.
These are the four.
There are four more dharmas: namely, purifying oneself, purifying all beings, purifying the Dharma, and purifying meditation;
These are the four.
There are four more dharmas: namely, calming the body, calming the mind, calming the Way, and calming the Dharma;

There are four more dharmas: namely, contemplating the Buddha in the Dharma, not in form; contemplating the Dharma in detachment, not in self; contemplating the Saá¹…gha in the unconditioned, not in the multitude; purifying the wisdom eye;

These are the four.

These are the four dharmas that bodhisattvas accomplish, quickly attaining supreme, perfect enlightenment and the profound Dharma-endurance.

When this Dharma was being spoken, the bodhisattva Inconceivable Light attained the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas, and with joy and exaltation rose up into the sky to the height of seven tÄla trees.
